posts.name: Amanda Bessette
posts.cooked:
Wow, I really enjoyed meeting so many amazing people at this event in Houston! An enormous congratulations to Thad House for earning the Volunteer of the Year award! Their dedication truly makes a difference in the community. It’s awesome hearing about all the cool stuff you guys are doing.

This year, we hosted two fantastic conference sessions. First, it was incredible to showcase how XRP works alongside WPILib. Second, we talked about the updates coming in SystemCore and how they’re enhancing our tools. For those interested in learning more about these topics, you can download the detailed slides from here.

We’re thrilled to offer a virtual alternative for those who missed out on the in-person sessions. Be sure to check back soon for more details.

A huge thank you goes out to everyone who attended our sessions and stopped by our booth. Without a doubt, everyone was just as excited about the new REBUILT™ product by Haas as we were!

link_counts.title: [FRC/FTC Blog] Updates on the Future Robot Controller

posts.name: Tyler
posts.cooked: I attended this session and I was wondering if it was possible to get the FIRST team discount on the XRP through DigiKey? I found where I can apply on SparkFun but as a MN team and with the DigiKey voucher, I’d much prefer to order from there.

posts.name: Amanda Bessette
posts.cooked: You can send an email to xrp@digikey.com to apply for the discount

posts.name: Robert Marsh
posts.cooked: Unfortunately, I wasn't able to attend the presentation (volunteering as an inspector), but the slides are really exciting. I'm especially looking forward to having a more seamless integration between our school's FIRST Robotics Competition platform and FIRST Tech Challenge, as that has long been a significant hurdle for FTC teams at our makerspace. Is this a 'not interested' or a 'too hard'? It is possible to programmatically generate Blockly or build blocks through an API. Microsoft MakeCode does Static Typescript to Blockly, and I've done something similar for a work hackathon. If Python-to-Blockly translation is a feature WPIlib would be interested in having, I'd be happy to help set it up.

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of your text:

The command-based structure in FTC FIRST Tech Challenge and being able to more easily combine simultaneous auto actions are both things I look forward to. Although it may take a few more years, this seems worth the wait. Additionally, subsystems maintaining their own periodic functions remain beneficial for controlling arms and elevators effectively.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: 4 posts were merged into an existing topic: 2025 WPILib Feedback

posts.name: Lyssia
posts.cooked: If Python-to- Blockly translation is a feature WPIlib would be interested in having, I’d be willing to help set it up. Im not super familiar with the setup WPIlib is planning on using, but I’d imagine the set of valid Python programs is a superset of the set of Python programs generated by Blockly, which would make translation back difficult.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Python-to-Blockly translation could be a valuable feature for WPIlib. If WPIlib were interested in implementing such a feature, I'd be happy to assist in setting it up. Honestly, I don’t see the value; as programs get more complex, we should be promoting students to transition to text-based code.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Ethan C
posts.cooked: Do we have recordings from either session? Were there any materials such as slides, handouts, or videos shown during the XRP session?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: There’s no recording of either session. We’re talking about doing a virtual session (either live or recorded) of the SystemCore talk, but not the XRP one. We’ll look into posting charts from the XRP session as well.
